oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Southern Pacific Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Southern Pacific (performance group) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Southern Pacific; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Southern Pacific member's John McFee and Keith Knudsen tell of how they named their albums County Line and Zuma based on places they surf -- (01:16) "Any Way the Wind Blows" is discussed by McFee, Knudsen and Biff Collie as a track used in the Pink Cadillac movie soundtrack by Clint Eastwood -- (02:13) "Any Way the Wind Blows" is defined as a career song by Knudsen and McFee tells of writing with Bernadette Peters and Nicolette Larson -- (03:55) Collie begins to tell a story of seeing Southern Pacific [incomplete] -- (04:07) McFee and Knudsen talk about their arrangement of the "Star Spangled Banner" -- (04:51) "I Can't Complain" is described by Knudsen as a normal feeling -- (05:21) Knudsen, McFee, and Collie joke about how Southern Pacific came together and tell of how they were originally members of the Doobie Brothers -- (06:33) Kurt Howell tells how he was a session artist and Knudsen touches on Stu Cook's time as a member of Creedence Clearwater Revival -- (07:46) McFee reminisces on his time as a guitar player and country artists pioneering electric guitar -- (08:20) Collie tells of Jimmy Rogers using a wide range of music to revolutionize country -- (09:15) Collie reflects on Bob Wills having a large orchestra backing him up to allow the band to join a union -- (10:00) "Beyond Love" writer Knudsen is discussed and Howell reflects on the idea of a romantic partner -- (11:08) Howell and Knudsen tells of Southern Pacific's fandom of surfing -- (12:02) McFee tells of "Times Up" being a song that developed into including Carlene Carter -- (13:53) "Memphis Queen" is discussed by Knudsen as a romantic song of riverboats -- (14:51) McFee discusses the stylist discussions that make them different -- (15:17) Collie and Howell talk about "G.T.O" originally being perceived as a Beach Boys song; the Southern Pacific group worked with the Beach Boys to complete the song -- (16:53) Knudsen tells of how their album format was perceived as only country and how that changed with "Side Saddle" -- (18:07) Knudsen jokes about writing another song [unidentified] -- (18:17) Knudsen tells of "Restless Heart" as a song with a certain type of feeling -- (19:04) Knudsen and Collie talk about the rodeo show circuit that they have been playing -- (19:59) McFee addresses Justin Boots and a rodeo relief fund they donate to -- (21:00) Collie and Southern Pacific discuss the decision to release their album and the royalty rate of the album -- (22:08) Southern Pacific joke about "The One that Got Away" being a fishing song; but, it is actually a love song -- (23:27) Knudsen tells of how the magic of a song can be changed drastically -- (24:15) "Mary Lou" is told by McFee as being discovered by Jim Ed Norman and addresses the number of songs they tried -- (25:25) "Help Wanted" is told by Knudsen as a story wrote by Knudsen by an experience in California and McFee jokes about the "Star Spangled Banner" -- (26:25) Collie addresses "I Go to Pieces" and Southern Pacific tells of how they recorded the acapella for the song; additionally, the decision was made while touring -- (29:10) Knudsen tells about the inability to test songs on tour except when they are performing live shows -- (30:18) Collie addresses his gratefulness and Southern Pacific joke about Collie's name relation to a dog
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Southern Pacific; Southern Pacific (Musical group);
